occurrences.line_text: Sith of things subiect to thy daily vew
Comaunded them their daily workes renew,
With daily shew of courteous kind behauiour,
So daily he faire semblant did her shew,
She daily told, her loue he did defye,
Vppon the rites and daily sacrifize,
He offred vp for daily sacrifize
To rescue her, and daily meanes assay,
Which daily may to thy sweete lookes repayre,
His best endeuour, and his daily paine,
For hauing long time, as his daily weed,
That he dare not returne for all his daily vaunt.
And my flockes father daily doth amend it.
And in the Princes gardin daily wrought:
That euen I which daily doe behold
For your meane food shall be my daily feast,
He daily did apply him selfe to donne
And daily more her fauour to augment;
With humble seruice, and with daily sute,
But darkenesse dred and daily night did houer
Through daily mourning, and nightly misfare:
Therefore to cherish him with diets daint,
In picturing the parts of beautie daint,
The diuerse vsage and demeanure daint,
Some with their eyes the daintest morsels chose;
And on the grasse her daintie limbes did lay
And daintie spices fetcht from furthest Ynd,
Her daintie limbes full softly down did lay:
His daintie corse, proud humors to abate,
Her daintie limbs in her sad dreriment,
And daintie deare, which on the ground still fell,
What needs of daintie dishes to deuize,
To spoile her daintie corse so faire and sheene,
Did out of order stray about her daintie eares.
Her daintie paps; which like young fruit in May
In daintie delices, and lauish ioyes,
Which daintie odours round about them threw,
Her daintie limbes aboue her tender hips,
No daintie flowre or herbe, that growes on ground,
A daintie damzell, dressing of her heare,
Into her cup she scruzd, with daintie breach
There the most daintie Paradise on ground,
Of all that mote delight a daintie eare,
She secretly would search each daintie lim,
Their daintie layes and dulcet melody,
And euery daintie limbe with horrour shake;
He daintie couch with teares, which closely she did weepe.
From scorching heat her daintie limbes to shade:
Or that same daintie lad, which was so deare
Manie a braue knight, and manie a daintie dame
No flowre in field, that daintie odour throwes,
Thereon distill, and deaw her daintie face,
Those daintie parts, the dearlings of delight,
Or other daintie thing for her addrest,
That doth despise the dainties of the towne.
With blossomes braue bedecked daintily;
And deckt with flowers and herbars daintily;
With diuerse flowres he daintily was deckt,
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
A girlond for her dainty forehead fit,
Where store they found of all, that dainty was and rare.
And deck with dainty flowres their bridall bed,
Their minds to pleasure, & their mouthes to dainty fare.
Their dainty parts from vew of any, which them eyde.
Him to a dainty flowre she did transmew,
Nought wanted there, that dainty was and rare;
Beside the same a dainty place there lay,
That dainty Rose, the daughter of her Morne,
From off their dainty limbes the dustie sweat,
Threw forth most dainty odours, & most sweet delight.
To be embaulm'd, and sweat out dainty dew,
Of dainty musicke, which did next ensew
Their dainty parts, which nature had created
To beare this burden on your dainty backe;
Oft whip her dainty selfe, and much augment her doole.
But of her dainty flesh they did deuize
Tell me, what mote these dainty Damzels be,
To make it seeme more deare and dainty, as is meet.
And ouerflow each plaine and lowly dale:
Downe in a dale, hard by a forests side,
But euery hill and dale, each wood and plaine
High ouer hils, and low adowne the dale,
Into a pleasant dale, that lowly lay
Still he him guided ouer dale and hill,
Into a shadie dale she soft him led,
Foreby a riuer in a pleasaunt dale,
Nor hedge, nor ditch, nor hill, nor dale she staies,
And chaced them both ouer hill and dale:
Downe in a dale forby a riuers syde,
Through hils and dales he speedie way did make,
The dales for shade, the hilles for breathing space,
High ouer hilles and ouer dales he fled,
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
The hils doe not the lowly dales disdaine;
The dales doe not the lofty hils enuy.
High ouer hilles, and lowly ouer dales,
Through hils & dales, through bushes & through breres
Through hils, through dales, throgh forests, & throgh plaines
Amongst poore hyndes, in hils, in woods, in dales,
Where he with his Duessa dalliance fownd,
Her once to show, ne court, nor dalliance,
Her dalliance he despisd, and follies did forsake.
Now faining dalliance and wanton sport,
To whom he made great dalliance and delight.
And coy lookes tempring with loose dalliance;
With faire disport and courting dalliaunce
Her light behauiour, and loose dalliaunce
Well warned to beware with whom he dar'd to dallie.
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
Their dam vpstart, out of her den effraide,
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
More deare vnto their God, then you[n]glings to their dam.
Lying in waite, how him he damadge might.
For all the damage, which he had him doen afore.
Like to a great Mill damb forth fiercely gusht,
He bad awake blacke Plutoes griesly Dame,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
Why Dame (quoth he) what hath ye thus dismayd?
He would not shend, but said, Deare dame I rew,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
On silly Dame, subiect to hard mischaunce,
And said, Deare dame, your suddein ouerthrow
Thensforth I tooke Duessa for my Dame,
Dame Vna, wearie Dame, and entrance did requere.
Dame Vna, wearie Dame, and entrance did requere.
He thereto meeting said, My dearest Dame,
And high disdaine, whenas his soueraine Dame
In choice, and change of thy deare loued Dame,
The royall Dame, and for her coche doth call:
Ah dearest Dame, (quoth then the Paynim bold,)
Thereto said he, Faire Dame be nought dismaid
Why dame (quoth he) what oddes can euer bee,
Saying, Yet O thou dreaded Dame, I craue
Vp then, vp dreary Dame, of darknesse Queene,
Ah Dame (quoth he) thou temptest me in vaine,
Returnd to stately pallace of dame Pride;
Sometimes Dame Venus selfe he seemes to see,
The fearefull Dame all quaked at the sight,
On gentle Dame, so hurtlesse, and so trew:
Aye me, Deare dame (quoth he) well may I rew
Ah dearest dame (quoth he) how might I see
Great maistresse of her art was that false Dame,
Yet goodly court he made still to his Dame,
Deare Dame (quoth he) you sleeping sparkes awake,
Dame Cï¿½lia men did her call, as thought
And afterwards them to his Dame he leades,
That aged Dame, the Ladie of the place:
That vp to heauen is blowne. The auncient Dame
Then said the aged Coelia, Deare dame,
And had he not that Dame respected more,
And doen their seruice to that soueraigne Dame,
Now O thou sacred Muse, most learned Dame,
Should haue mine onely daughter to his Dame,
Or wrapped be in loues of former Dame,
Fidessa hight the falsest Dame on ground,
Ah farre be it (said he) Deare dame fro mee,
By great Dame Nature, from whose fruitfull pap
A sober sad, and comely curteous Dame;
He that made loue vnto the eldest Dame,
O wretched man, that would abuse so gentle Dame.
On gallow trees, in honour of his dearest Dame.
His dearest Dame is that Enchaunteresse,
Ah Dame, perdie ye haue not doen me right,
Themselues did solace each one with his Dame,
The bowels of wide Fraunce, a forlorne Dame,
Who had to wife Dame Mertia the fayre,
Such as Dame Nature selfe mote feare to see,
Vnder that Porch a comely dame did rest,
And some for wrath, to see their captiue Dame:
Most goodly meede, the fairest Dame aliue:
To chaunge my liefe, and loue another Dame,
That she is fairer, then our fairest Dame,
'Mongst thousands good one wanton Dame to find:
Nought so of loue this looser Dame did skill,
Gan choose his dame with Basciomani gay,
The loathed leachour. But the Dame halfe ded
And that old Dame said many an idle verse,
And choseth vertue for his dearest Dame,
Begin then, ï¿½ my dearest sacred Dame,
And great Dame Natures handmaide, chearing euery kind.
Of my deare Dame is loued dearely well;
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
Dame Phoebe to a Nymph her babe betooke,
Wherewith dame Nature doth her beautifie,
And tell the idle tidings to his Dame:
And was return'd againe vnto his Dame,
To make another like the former Dame,
He gan make gentle purpose to his Dame,
In th'heart of euery honourable Dame,
And shewd her selfe in all a gentle curteous Dame.
Purpose was moued by that gentle Dame,
From Lacedï¿½mon fetcht the fairest Dame,
Vpon his lips hong faire Dame Hellenore,
This second Hellene, faire Dame Hellenore,
Both was he loth to loose his loued Dame,
Sith I enioyd the gentlest Dame aliue;
But let vs go to seeke my dearest Dame,
And loue a Shepheards daughter for his dearest Dame.
He loued Isse for his dear est Dame,
After all these there marcht a most faire Dame,
Faire Dame he might behold in perfect kind;
But if that thou this Dame doe presently
Said, Gentle Dame, reward enough I weene
Where many a knight, and many a louely Dame
Take then to you this Dame of mine (quoth hee)
The aged Dame him seeing so enraged,
And sayd, Fond dame that deem'st of things diuine
And rather stird by his discordfull Dame,
Manie a braue knight, and manie a daintie dame
Dame Venus girdle, by her steemed deare,
Graunted to her, as to the fayrest Dame.
For that strange Dame, whose beauties wonderment
First in the midst to set that fayrest Dame,
And that old aged Dame, his faithfull Squire,
That peerelesse paterne of Dame natures pride,
And you faire Ladie knight, my dearest Dame,
Ne euer Knight so bold, ne euer Dame
And told his Dame, her Squire of low degree
Not to despise that dame, which lou'd him liefe,
The warlike Dame was on her part assaid,
But therein sate an amiable Dame,
Nathlesse that Dame so well them tempred both,
The noursling of Dame Memorie his deare,
Next came the aged Ocean, and his Dame,
Dame Venus sonne that tameth stubborne youth
That had despisde so chast and faire a dame,
That was to succour a distressed Dame,
He askt, who had that Dame so fouly dight;
And eke their dame halfe dead did hide her self for feare.
Vpon the way, with that his snowy Dame.
What better dowre can to a dame be hight?
Euen so Clarinda her owne Dame beguyld,
And him she told, her Dame his freedome did denye.
Yet to her Dame him still she discommended,
Then backe returning, where his Dame did lie,
But this proude Dame disdayning all accord,
By that proud dame, which her so much disdained,
Who all that wrong vnto that wofull Dame
Declare it boldly Dame, and doe not stand in dout.
Why then will ye, fond Dame, attempted bee
Where that discourteous Dame with scornfull pryde,
Thereto great helpe dame Nature selfe doth lend:
Through thicke and thin, vnfit for any Dame.
For what he spake, for you he spake it, Dame;
Ye dolefull Dame, let not your griefe empeach
And to her said; Dame be no longer sad:
For safe conducting of his sickely Dame,
For pitty of his Dame, whom she saw so diseased.
But most for pitty of his dearest Dame,
What be you wofull Dame, which thus lament,
A wofull dame ye haue me termed well;
Then thus began the lamentable Dame;
And hauing cheared her, thus said; faire Dame,
Albe that Dame by all the meanes she might,
By gentle vsage of that wretched Dame.
Tho backe returning to that sorie Dame,
To draw him from his deare beloued dame,
The wretchedst Dame, that liue this day on ground;
Vnto their iourney; but that Squire and Dame
The Hermite heales both Squire and dame
Made in the bodies of that Squire and Dame;
And thus he to them sayd; Faire daughter Dame,
And eke his Dame him seeing in such guize,
Into the chamber, where that Dame remayned
All other Dames to haue exceeded farre;
By that same way the direfull dames doe driue
And be for all chast Dames an endlesse moniment.
Apes, Lions, ï¿½/-gles, Owles, fooles, louers, children, Dames.
Satyrane saues the Squire of Dames
Call me the Squyre of Dames that me beseemeth well.
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
But read, thou Squyre of Dames, what vow is this,
I might do seruice vnto gentle Dames,
Till I so many other Dames had found,
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
Who hauing ended with that Squire of Dames
Ye noble knights (said then the Squire of Dames)
Redoubted knights, and honorable Dames,
From whom the Squire of Dames was reft whylere;
Was from those Dames so farre and so vnfitting,
Had not a Squire, euen he the Squire of Dames,
Which when that scornefull Squire of Dames did vew,
Plenty of pearles to decke his dames withall,
This day, to wreake the dammage by thee donne:
To doe most dammage, where as most they ment.
Had damn'd her sonnes, which gainst them did rebell,
To damne him selfe by euery euill name;
Fluttring about his euer damned hed,
As one aghast with feends or damned sprights,
What voyce of damned Ghost from Limbo lake,
Then groning deepe, Nor damned Ghost, (quoth he,)
And damned sprights sent forth to make ill men aghast.
Whereas the damned ghosts in torments fry,
And to the villein said, Thou damned wight,
The damned ghosts, that doe in torments waile,
Whom when the damned feend so fresh did spy,
For nigh thereto the euer damned beast
Does scorch not halfe so sore, nor damned ghoste
And looking downe, saw many damned wights,
In which the damned soules he did behold,
Through which the damned ghosts doen often creepe
There let her with the damned spirits dwell,
Out of the dwellings of the damned sprights,
Yet was he iustly damned by the doome
There let her euer keepe her damned den,
Against Duessa, damned by them all;
So her he deemes already but a damned ghoste.
And damned to endure this direfull smart,
That swarmes of damned soules to hell he sends:
Where with such damned fiends she should in darknesse dwell.
And to the other damned ghosts, which dwell
As if late fight had nought him damnifyde,
To see my Lord so deadly damnifyde
Cursing his Gods, and himselfe damning deepe:
Damon and Pythias whom death could not seuer;
That mirrhour, wherein the sicke Damosell
Th'aduenture of the Errant damozell,
For thy, faire Sir, yours be the Damozell,
More need of leach-craft hath your Damozell,
To take that way, in which that Damozell
Ye wonder, how this noble Damozell
What end vnto that fearefull Damozell,
About the chamber with that Damozell,
And fresh Aurora had the shady damp
And misty dampe of misconceiuing night,
Sith shady dampe had dimd the heauens reach,
By this the day with dampe was ouercast,
Bad doe away the dampe of drouzie sleepe,
All suddenly dim woxe the dampish ayre,
The drowzie humour of the dampish night,
But when he saw the Damsell passe away
Themselues to court, and each a Damsell chose:
Another Damsell of that gentle crew,
And borne of two faire Damsels, which were taught,
A damzell spyde slow footing her before,
The doubtfull Damzell dare not yet commit
Or euer gentle Damzell so abuse:
And all the way, the wanton Damzell found
Ne staied for his Damzell to inquire,
Besought that Damzell suffer him depart,
And to that Damzell thankes gaue for reward.
Faire Damzell, seemeth, by your troubled cheare,
A daintie damzell, dressing of her heare,
That of a single damzell thou wert met
Ne list me chaunge; she th'Errant Damzell hight,
But the chaste damzell, that had neuer priefe
Therefore, faire Damzell, be ye well aware,
The Damzell well did vew his personage,
The Damzell pauzd, and then thus fearefully;
For the faire Damzell from the holy herse
The Damzell was full deepe empassioned,
Of the young Damzell sunke, that great desire
The fearefull damzell, with incessant paines:
To that faire Damzell: Him he chaced long
The Damzell there arriuing entred in;
To which the Damzell full of doubtfull thought,
Whom when the fearefull Damzell nigh espide,
The third a Damzell was of low degree,
This gentle Damzell, whom I wrote vpon,
The warlike Damzell was empassiond sore,
But the stout Damzell to him leaping light,
Euery of which was to a damzell hight;
Th'enchaunted Damzell vanisht into nought:
Loue that same other Damzell, Lucy bright,
But this same other Damzell since hath fained,
Goe damzell quickly, doe thy selfe addresse,
The Damzell streight obayd, and putting all
Where that same Damzell lowdly him bespake,
Faire Damzell, that with ruth (as I perceaue)
A Damzell, flying on a palfrey fast
Which when the Damzell, who those deadly ends
And lo the Damzell selfe, whence all did grow,
Then they that Damzell called to them nie,
So said this Damzell, that hight Samient,
And then that Damzell, the sad Samient,
That Damzell, led her to the Souldans right.
Which brought that Damzell, as his purchast pray;
That Damzell, whom he held as wrongfull prisonere.
As this bold woman, when she saw that Damzell there.
Vnto that Damzell in her Ladies right,
Mongst which that Damzell did to them bewray
Which when the Damzell neare at hand did spy,
The Damzell straight went, as she was directed,
Him when the damzell saw fast by her side,
There they alighting, by that Damzell were
A Damzell vsed vylde:
With a faire Damzell, my beloued deare,
And to his damzell as their rightfull meed,
But this coy Damzell thought contrariwize,
The damzell was attacht, and shortly brought
The Damzell wakes, then all attonce vpstart,
The Damzell was before the altar set,
Saw a faire damzell, which did weare a crowne
That wild the damzell rise; the day did now expyre.
Another Damzell, as a precious gemme,
The trustie damzell bearing it abrode
Vntill the damzell gan to wex more sound and strong.
Two naked Damzelles he therein espyde,
Amidst a flocke of Damzels fresh and gay,
And all was full of Damzels, and of Squires,
By this her Damzels, which the former chace
She made those Damzels search, which being stayd,
And woxe halfe wroth against her damzels slacke,
She was well pleasd, and forth her damzels sent,
Kings Queenes, Lords Ladies, Knights & Damzels gent
For all the Priests were damzels, in soft linnen dight.
A beuie of fayre damzels close did lye,
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
And them beside two seemely damzels stood,
But euermore, those Damzels did forestall
Guarded with many damzels, that did waite
And all the damzels of that towne in ray,
To th'heards, but meant them to the damzels fantazy.
Tell me, what mote these dainty Damzels be,
Are Venus Damzels, all within her fee,
Dan Faunus chaunst to meet her by the way,
And all his windes Dan Aeolus did keepe,
To shew Dan Cupids powre and great effort:
Dan Chaucer, well of English vndefyled,
For which Dan Phebus selfe cannot a salue prouide.
As when Dan AEolus in great displeasure,
Him selfe he chaung'd faire Danaï¿½ to vew,
Then those, which haue bene dandled in the lap.
The danger hid, the place vnknowne and wilde,
For danger great, if not assur'd decay
Now freed from feare and danger of that dismall wight.
Whose dangerous successe depended yet in dout.
That is both swift and dangerous deepe withall;
There chaunst to them a dangerous accident;
And dangerously did round about enclose.
Mo[N]Gst thousand dangers, & ten thousand magick mights.
Huge monsters haunt, and many dangers dwell;
Fro dangers dread his doubtfull life to saue;
She wore much like vnto a Danisk hood
That from the Daniske Tyrants head shall rend
And then Kimarus, and then Danius;
He Easterland subdewd, and Danmarke wonne,
Whiles trembling horror did his conscience dant,
Faire Daphne Phoebus hart with loue did gore;
Fled fearefull Daphne on th'ï¿½gï¿½an strond,
To loue faire Daphne, which thee loued lesse:
More swift then Myrrh' or Daphne in her race,
Whose sides with dapled circles weren dight;
Fast flying on a Courser dapled gray,
A bold bad man, that dar'd to call by name
Had wrought that horror strange, and dar'd his dreaded powre.
Well warned to beware with whom he dar'd to dallie.
Ne any dar'd their perill to partake;
That from close friends, that dar'd not to appeare,
Ne dare to weepe, nor seeme to vnderstand
That victory they dare not wish to either side.
To dare the thing, which daily yet I rew,
The doubtfull Damzell dare not yet commit
How dare I thinke such glory to attaine?
Dare not aduenture on the stubborne pray,
Dare not for dread his hardy hand expose,
But dare thou not, I charge, in any cace,
That euer hand should dare for to engore
Both first and second Troy shall dare to equalise.
And you most noble Lord, that can and dare
That he dare neuer sleepe, but that one eye
That dare fro me thinke Florimell to take.
Ne dare I like, but through infusion sweete
All which who so dare thinke for to enchace,
And breaking forth, dare tempt the deepest flood,
That dare discourse of so diuine a read,
That with his souce, which none enduren dare,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
But he the man, that say or doe so dare,
That none should dare him once to entertaine:
Vnlesse thou dare for thy deare Ladies sake,
That he dare not returne for all his daily vaunt.
Ne euer armes, ne euer knighthood dare
Which what it dare not doe by open might,
To dare not to pollute so sacred threasure,
Firme Chastity, that spight ne blemish dare;
How could the death dare euer her to quell?
For neuer knight, that dared warlike deede,
Yet dared not his victour to withstand,
And dared of all sinnes the secrets to vnfold.
And the still Darent, in whose waters cleane
At perill past, and yet in doubt ne dares
With which he dares our offers thus despize.
Ne any dares with him for it debate.
That darest vew my direfull countenaunce,
For daring tempt the Queene of heauen to sin;
Yet to lay hand on her, not one of all them daring.
That none his daunger daring to abide,
A diuerse dreame out of his prison darke,
And her darke griesly looke them much dismay;
By that same hole an entrance darke and bace
Deepe, darke, vneasie, dolefull, comfortlesse,
But all a deepe descent, as darke as hell,
Darke, dolefull, drearie, like a greedie graue,
Wherein darke things were writ, hard to be vnderstood.
So darke are earthly things compard to things diuine.
Through which into his darke abisse all rauin fell.
From heauen high to chase the chearelesse darke,
As lump of lead, and made darke clouds appeare;
Does waste his dayes in darke obscuritee,
